title: Daily Market Digest: February 16, 2026
subtitle: US Markets Closed for Presidents' Day Amid AI Concerns and Mixed Global Sentiment

items.headline: US Markets Closed for Presidents' Day; Global Equities Show Mixed Performance
items.summary: U.S. stock markets are closed today in observance of Presidents' Day. Major indices ended last week on a weaker footing, pressured by renewed concerns over artificial intelligence (AI) related capital expenditure and potential structural disruption to industries. Market sentiment globally remains cautious, with some Asian and European markets showing mixed activity. Investors are digesting recent economic data, including moderated US inflation and resilient labor market figures, which have shifted Federal Reserve rate cut expectations.

items.statContext: US market closed. Declined 1.4% last week.
US market closed. Nasdaq 100 declined 1.4% and Nasdaq Composite dropped 2.1% last week.
US market closed. Retreated 1.2% last week.

items.headline: Natco Pharma Surges on Semaglutide Approval
items.summary: Shares of Indian pharmaceutical firm Natco Pharma ($NATCO) gained significantly after receiving approval from India's Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) to manufacture and market generic Semaglutide injection.

items.headline: Austal Limited Leads Australian Gainers
items.summary: Australian shipbuilder Austal Limited (ASX: ASB) was a top performer on the S&P/ASX 200, boosted by market activity.

items.headline: CBRE Group Plunges Amid AI Disruption Fears
items.summary: Real estate service company CBRE Group saw a significant decline last week, as AI disruption concerns extended beyond software to sectors like wealth management and real estate.

items.headline: Fortescue Ltd Among Australian Losers
items.summary: Australian mining giant Fortescue Ltd (ASX: FMG) experienced a notable decline during today's trading session.

items.headline: Sector Rotation Underway as AI Concerns Shift Market Focus
items.summary: The market is experiencing a significant rotation, with capital moving away from high-multiple software names towards 'Real Economy' sectors such as Value, Infrastructure, and Staples. Last week, AI disruption concerns led to sell-offs in wealth management, real estate, and logistics companies in the US. Conversely, in Australia, Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, and Healthcare sectors showed gains. Indian markets saw defensive and consumption-linked indices, including FMCG, pharma, healthcare, and realty, outperform. Information technology, financials, and consumer discretionary sectors are down year-to-date in the S&P 500.

items.headline: Economic Data and Fed Outlook Shape Investor Expectations
items.summary: US markets are closed today for Presidents' Day, but recent economic data continues to influence the outlook. Last week, non-farm payrolls increased by 130,000, and the unemployment rate unexpectedly fell to 4.3%. Headline consumer inflation moderated to 2.4% year-on-year, with core inflation also retreating to 2.4%. This unexpected resilience in the labor market has shifted Federal Reserve rate cut expectations from June to July 2026, with some pricing in further reductions by March 2027. The minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest FOMC meeting are expected to be released on Wednesday, providing further insights into monetary policy. Additionally, advance fourth-quarter GDP figures and PCE inflation data for December are due on Friday.

items.headline: Key Earnings Reports This Week and Notable Releases
items.summary: Several companies are scheduled to report earnings this week, including Walmart ($WMT), Warner Bros. Discovery, Booking Holdings ($BKNG), Deere & Company ($DE), and Palo Alto Networks ($PANW). Today, ReNew Energy Global ($RNW) is hosting its Q3 2026 earnings call. Other companies reporting today include Sonoco Products Company ($SON), Otter Tail Corporation ($OTTR), Tennant Company ($TNC), and Armada Hoffler Properties, Inc. ($AHH). Ansell reported a 19% increase in adjusted earnings per share despite flat revenue for its first half. Indian company Ola Electric reported a narrower net loss in Q3.

items.headline: International Markets React to Local Data and Global Trends
items.summary: Japanese markets saw mixed trading today after data showed the economy expanded just 0.1% annually in the December quarter, below forecasts. However, Japan's economy returned to growth in the final quarter of 2025, potentially clearing the way for rate hikes. Chinese mainland markets are closed for the week-long Lunar New Year holiday, impacting activity across Asia. The Renminbi has strengthened to a 33-month high against the dollar. The FTSE 100 continued to trade near record highs as expectations for Bank of England rate cuts increased due to signs of UK economic weakness.
